John Smith.Action: Described as a warm-hearted rebel and a lover of play and song.
Sitting in irons awaiting hanging on a charge of mutiny, not on deck with crew during critical landing moment.
Described as a warm-hearted rebel, a lover of play and song.
Speaks his mind without mincing words, convinced he must always be right, even in small matters.
Long accustomed to the disfavor of his superiors and lacking diplomatic skill.
Has survived numerous hardships including slavery, imprisonment, battles, and shipwrecks, showing resilience and daring.
Chooses a career relying solely on daring with no rank, property, education, or connections.
Is a true pioneer, confronting danger and fear contemptuously, and moves on when bored to seek luck elsewhere.
Admits to others, including Wingfield, that people are often cruel and brutish, implying a cynical view of human nature and suggesting that cruelty commands respect and fear.
Stands unperturbed while facing a noose, showing calmness and composure under threat but revealing resignation rather than hope or connection.
Stands unperturbed on the stool while about to be hanged, showing calmness and confidence.
Speaks intelligently about human nature and logic, indicating thoughtfulness and intelligence.
Does not make any visible attempt to escape or plead, relying instead on his understanding of logic and human behavior.
Gives Wingfield a broad smile despite tensions.
Swaggers around ignoring shipmates' congratulations, showing confidence but little engagement.
Engages in conversation with Ben the cook, responding calmly and curiously.
Ignores shipmates’ congratulations, swaggers with hardy confidence, inspiring respect; wears his armor boldly despite heat; carries off his bold, outlandish manner convincingly.
Makes mutinous remarks leading to threat of punishment, requiring others to intervene for his release.
Smiles and expresses liking for his mates and the place he enjoys in their hearts.
Replies to Ben's insults with a calm, somewhat dismissive remark and then walks off, avoiding escalation.
Shows openness and attempts to build trust with the natives through shared gestures and expressions of common humanity.
No direct actions or statements by John Smith in the provided excerpt, showing no display of competence or incompetence.
Tries to call the Indians back after a violent incident to restore trust.
Drags the bosun into the water and repeatedly submerges his head to punish him publicly, disregarding the Indians’ understanding.
Subdues the bosun with physical courage when the bosun strikes back at him.
Subdues the bosun quickly with swift physical courage when the bosun strikes back at him.
Tries to call the retreating Indians back after the confrontation but fails to regain their trust.
Punishes the bosun by dunking his head underwater repeatedly to demonstrate authority and discipline in front of the Indians.
No direct actions or statements by John Smith in this excerpt.
Waves to Pocahontas and smiles at her playful gesture despite needing to remain on guard.
Observes cabin boys inflamed by Pocahontas’s presence without intervening or expressing disapproval.
Sits with a sketch board, carefully drawing and studying the strange varieties of plants he discovered.
Waves to Pocahontas and smiles but consciously decides not to leave his post to join her, staying on guard as required.
Accepts responsibility to be envoy to the 'Savage King' despite the hazardous nature of the mission.
Accepts the role of envoy to negotiate with the Savage King due to being the only professional soldier and suited for the hazardous mission.
Bows respectfully and accepts opportunity to repair reputation
Shares personal hardships and vulnerability about his past experiences and hope for a special destiny
Accepts opportunity to repair his reputation with a bow and says 'I do.'
Faces the prospect of setting off in the shallop without fear when asked if afraid.
Recounts survival through extreme and dangerous situations with calm confidence and hope.
Expresses ambitious plans to achieve what no one has done before — finding the way through to the Indies.
Protects his group despite their flaws, accepts responsibility for them.
Remains silent when his men express concern about danger.
Maintains silence and assesses the helmsman's warning before signaling to put in to shore, showing situational awareness and prudent decision-making.
Bows and boards the shallop prepared with provisions, reflecting readiness and respect for responsibility.
Leads a group of armed men up a mysterious and potentially dangerous river, maintaining composure despite signs of unrest among his men.
Describes the new land and its people optimistically and with a hopeful vision of fairness and freedom, emphasizing nobility without slavery or deceit.
Feels a mutiny brewing among the English party but does not escalate conflict, instead tries to inspire hope with his account.
Smith recognizes a brewing mutiny and attempts to inspire and reassure the party by recounting tales of abundance and opportunity in the new land, showing leadership and motivational skill.
Expresses uncertainty verbally ('I don’t know whether to credit this'), demonstrating cautiousness and intellectual honesty rather than blind confidence.
Fails to prevent the sailors from wandering off and falling into danger, showing some lack of control over the group.
Encourages men to make a choice between freedom and stagnation, appealing to their hopes rather than condemning them.
Allows a deserter guide (Tomocomo) to leave without punishment, despite having authority to hang him.
Calls the rest of the men a 'flock of ducks,' favoring only two volunteers, showing some impatience and possible disdain.
Jokes with men in the canoe by asking if he was impressive, showing a friendly and somewhat playful demeanor.
Motivates men with a confident speech about freedom and choice, choosing to continue the dangerous mission with only two volunteers rather than abandon it.
Allows a guide to desert but accepts the risk and moves forward with limited support, showing decisiveness.
Continues the journey despite the clear dangers of wilderness, heavy armor, and possible drowning, driven by an undefined intuition.
Fails to answer when asked if he knows their location or their purpose, indicating some possible uncertainty or withholding information.
Encourages his men to keep their matchlocks lit and signals readiness despite dangers, showing leadership and reassurance.
Maintains confidence by telling Emery to imagine they won’t be hit by arrows, aiming to calm fears.
Does not pursue the Indian guide who deserts him, indicating restraint and possibly respect or non-aggression.
Moves forward alone into dangerous territory, focused on the surroundings and his mission, not explicitly showing care or connection to others.
Brings a compass and rule to make a map, showing planning and foresight.
Discharges his musket proactively to assert control and scout.
Straps on his siege helmet and proceeds into hostile wilderness despite warnings.
Instructs companions to keep matchlocks lit and signal, showing tactical awareness.
Dismisses fears of incoming arrows, encouraging confidence.
Continues moving forward despite being totally lost after guide deserts him.
Does not pursue the deserting guide, possibly missing an opportunity to regain direction.
Turns back upon hearing a cry and suspects danger to companions, showing situational awareness.
Hears arrows, two ricochet off armor and one wounds him. Removes the arrow skillfully and readies halberd to defend.
Shoots the boldest Indian in the hand with his pistol when they touch him like children playing tag.
Offers his weapon to the Indian leader with great flourish instead of begging for mercy.
Leaps to his feet and presents a small box with a compass to the Indian chief with a deep bow.
Turns the box upside down and looks at it carefully, maintaining dignity before his soldiers.
Requests a soldier to fetch his musket calmly despite being a prisoner.
Expresses delight upon seeing the cultivated fields and orderly city rather than hostile savages.
Turns the box upside down and examines it carefully while maintaining dignity before his soldiers.
Confidently asks for his musket even while effectively a prisoner.
Remains observant and astonished upon seeing Werowocomoco, noting details of the city and the cultivated fields, showing situational awareness.
Passively is led into captivity without resistance or attempts to escape/not escape mentioned.
Shows no emotion when presented with the remains of his late comrades, maintaining composure.
Responds honestly and clearly when questioned by the interpreter about his origin and purpose.
States intention to push on despite harsh circumstances and inability to leave till spring.
Attempts to negotiate and trade for food and comforts, showing diplomatic skill.
Directly appeals to Powhatan's sense of community with a rhetorical question 'Don’t you love your neighbors?'.
Demonstrates knowledge and shows power by igniting gunpowder to impress the natives.
Makes a somewhat flippant remark about being fattened up, showing some confidence but possibly undermining diplomacy.
Snatches up his sword when threatened, showing readiness to defend himself.
Smith’s sword is left carelessly nearby by captors, suggesting a possible lack of fear or hostile intent on his part.
Remains calm and accepting when braves seize him for execution, showing no fear.
Remains calm and unafraid while being dragged to execution, showing composure in a life-threatening situation.
Does not attempt to negotiate or escape when brought before stones for execution, potentially missing an opportunity for self-preservation or strategic action.
Tolerates and accepts the seemingly hostile but then friendly treatment by Powhatan’s people without aggression or complaint.
Speaks gently to Pocahontas to reassure her and gains her trust despite tense circumstances.
Remains calm and composed when suddenly treated as a conquering hero despite being moments away from death; does not panic or act rashly in confusing social situations.
His look of perplexity in response to the unexpected honor shows some uncertainty or confusion in interpreting the situation.
Reassures Pocahontas not to be afraid, offers to do small acts of kindness like picking up a leaf repeatedly to please her.
Does not understand Pocahontas's pantomime, but continues to engage patiently.
Responds confidently when asked if he would pick up a leaf again, showing willingness and attentiveness.
Does not understand what she means in pantomime, indicating a momentary lack of perceptiveness.
Exchanges greetings warmly with Parahunt and Wobblehead; accepted as a brother by the Indians except Opechancanough.
Parts gradually with English dress and manners, adopting deerskin robe and headdress, showing openness and respect for native culture.
Reflects deeply on another way of living, beyond force and struggle, showing growing tolerance and possibly humility.
Substitutes his English dress piece by piece with a deerskin robe and headdress to fit in better with the Indians.
Is teased for his English manners and swordsmanship mistake in the woods, indicating initial lack of skill or awkwardness.
Gradually comes to find new ways of existing beyond European ideas of strength and struggle, showing adaptability and open-mindedness.
Patiently teaches Pocahontas English, gently explaining the vastness of the world with simple illustrations.
Internal conflict about leaving the Indians and betraying his newfound vision, showing openness but also hesitation.
Assumes the dress and manners of the Indians, showing adaptability and openness to new ways of existing.
Engages in teaching Pocahontas English, demonstrating leadership, communication skills, and cultural bridging.
Acknowledges the limits of his vision and knowledge about the world honestly.
Despite recognizing a new outlook, he half-knows he will betray his vision later, showing some internal conflict or lack of full commitment.
Patiently answers Pocahontas's repeated questions about the world beyond water.
Gently admits his inability to keep a bird on his finger or catch fish with his hands, showing humility.
Listens attentively and silently to Pocahontas' explanation about her ancestors and beliefs without interruption.
Explains the concept of distant lands and political states with reasoned detail and clarity to Pocahontas, showing knowledge and confidence.
Admits he cannot catch a fish with his hands or keep a bird on his finger, showing honest self-awareness of his limitations.
Replies honestly to Pocahontas’s questions without condescension and follows her when she runs off.
Spends time with Pocahontas engaging in activities like swimming and exploring nature together.
Shares knowledge by bringing a book of drawings of London to show Pocahontas.
Responds thoughtfully to Pocahontas' challenging questions about knowledge and existence, indicating openness to other ways of understanding.
Admits he does not know answers to some natural and spiritual phenomena Pocahontas asks about.
Follows Pocahontas respectfully and learns from her, demonstrating adaptability and willingness to learn.
Catches Pocahontas's hand and gently asks if she wants him to hold it.
Sits her imagination on fire by explaining unfamiliar objects and places thoughtfully.
Expresses sincere love and a profound personal change, valuing her above former ambitions.
Teases Pocahontas gently about admiring herself in the mirror.
Gives Pocahontas lessons in astronomy, plays and laughs with her and her friends, watches them with delight.
Refuses Pocahontas's offer to help carry logs, saying 'Under no circumstances! I will not see you dishonored.'
Calls Pocahontas a 'little pixie' or sprite, teasing her affectionately.
Gives Pocahontas lessons in astronomy, explains complex concepts in an engaging and playful manner.
Refuses Pocahontas's offer to help carry logs to protect her honor, showing protective judgment and self-restraint.
Uses humor and gentle teasing in conversation to ease tension and build rapport.
Expresses deep love sincerely to Pocahontas, kisses her hand, and promises eternal love.
Makes a somewhat harsh comment wishing all women would die at once so they won't outlive him.
Stumbles physically and admits losing balance.
Expresses deep emotions and love confidently and poetically.
Responds sincerely and pledges commitment through symbolic gestures.
Refuses to escape despite opportunity, choosing to stay with Pocahontas, showing loyalty and trust.
Affectionately embraces Pocahontas and kisses her forehead, showing tenderness and care.
Is frightened by the depth of Pocahontas's response, indicating sensitivity and vulnerability.
Questions Pocahontas to understand her intentions, showing openness and sincerity in communication.
Successfully eludes Pocahontas's retinue to find a peaceful spot with her, showing capability in stealth and evasion.
Responds calmly to Pocahontas's test of his commitment and fear, showing emotional intelligence and self-awareness.
Expresses fear and uncertainty internally after the intimate moment, indicating self-doubt and lack of full emotional control.
Feels a bond with Powhatan's people that he did not feel before.
Wants to speak honestly with Powhatan but keeps silent because he cannot express himself fully.
Promises to convey Powhatan's message truthfully to his own people.
Understands Algonquin without needing an interpreter, engages directly with Powhatan, and replies in English.
Wants to speak honestly but remains silent due to language limitations.
Promise to accurately report Powhatan’s words, showing responsibility and trustworthiness.
Speaks to Powhatan emphasizing peace and love over war; acknowledges Powhatan's daughter vouching for him as a good man; expresses hope for quiet days and long life and belief in living in peace.
Engages in diplomatic dialogue with Powhatan, showing understanding and confidence in peaceful coexistence.
Does not escalate the conflict but tries to find common ground and expresses hope for peace.
Smiles confidently at Powhatan and expresses belief in working out differences, showing diplomatic skill and confidence.
Accepts the offering of a valuable gift with appropriate respect and composure, reflecting awareness and social skill.
Walks with arm over Pocahontas' shoulder, showing personal confidence and emotional intelligence in interaction.
Asks Pocahontas if she trusts him and responds with a calm, thoughtful demeanor, indicating self-assurance and interpersonal competence.
Expresses concern about the favor of kings but does not complain or lash out; accepts his difficult situation with stoicism.
Signals readiness to leave despite emotional pain, showing a certain sense of responsibility over personal desire.
Interacts with the Indians respectfully as they escort him blindfolded, does not show hostility.
Upon arrival, calmly gestures for the Indians to set down their gifts, indicating consideration and respect.

Picks up his armor and carries it confidently, follows the blindfolded caravan through the woods, and consciously steps into an uncertain situation at Jamestown Fort, showing deliberate will and control.
Enters the fort despite potential danger, navigating through a tense environment with sleeping sentries and hostile attitudes, suggesting situational awareness and composure.
Asks about the wellbeing of the fort and the fate of Captain Newport and Ratcliffe, showing concern for the situation and the people.
Inquires about the dire situation and missing leaders, showing awareness and concern.
Does not intervene immediately in the worsening crisis despite clear signs of failing leadership and morale.
Looks at his captors coldly and does not react aggressively despite being cuffed.
States that as a good citizen, he ignores stories that bring officialdom into disrepute.
Removes a knife slyly, indicating readiness to defend himself but not immediately attacking.
Looks at captors coldly and slyly removes a knife from his hat, indicating readiness and cleverness.
Responds calmly and sarcastically to Wingfield's accusations, maintaining composure.
Ignores stories that undermine officialdom, showing political awareness.
Does not resist arrest or argue excessively despite being stripped of captaincy, possibly showing restraint.
Remains silent and does not respond to provocation from Wingfield.
Maintains stoic defiance when provoked by Wingfield, showing composure in a tense situation.
Questions Wingfield's authority to judge him, indicating awareness and assertiveness.
Does not react impulsively or with visible anger despite accusations and threats.
Lacks explicit strategic or problem-solving actions in the excerpt, mostly responds verbally.
Feels disgust at the selfishness and greed of others and resolves never to be like them again.
Draws his sword to defend against Wingfield’s men and skillfully overpowers them, inspiring others to join him.
Stares stunned at Argall’s murder of Wingfield and immediately orders Argall’s arrest.
With dazzling skill, he dispatches three opponents despite being outnumbered.
Stares stunned at Argall’s murder of Wingfield, showing hesitation or shock.
Immediately attempts to restore order by ordering Argall arrested after the murder.
Gives gifts to men that boost morale, leading them to cheer and carry him on their shoulders.
Rolls up his sleeves and helps with the colony's physical labor despite his status.
Uses wise and clever leadership to settle disputes among men, gaining their respect.
Jokes and interacts in a friendly manner with men like Ben and Ackley.
Responds seriously to concerns about gold, emphasizing survival and practical needs over riches.
Leads the men with confidence, is cheered by them, and takes initiative to supervise restoration and actively participates in physical work.
Handles disputes among men wisely and cleverly, earning their respect.
Maintains unconventional habits (wearing war paint, sleeping outside) showing confidence and adaptability in leadership role.
Responds to concerns about gold by refocusing priorities towards survival and practical resources (corn seed), demonstrating realistic judgment.
Avoids eye contact when discussing harsh conditions, disparages the place and people harshly.
Expresses sympathy and internal conflict about loyalty to English versus sympathy for the Indians.
Shows concern for Ackley, asks if he is all right and encourages him to have hope.
Dismisses others' concerns and potential danger, implying indifference to their safety.
Clearly assesses the poor condition of the land honestly and realistically, refusing to sugarcoat the truth.
Runs a flag up the rigging and prepares to sail alone, confident in taking risks others avoid.
Avoids direct eye contact when questioned, which may indicate evasiveness or lack of transparency.
Issues clear and strategic orders regarding sentry posting and waiting, showing command ability.
Feels a deep connection and hope inspired by the Indian girl, experiences genuine emotional unfolding and tenderness when with her, kisses her hand gently.
Collects a sack of copper hatchets, beads, combs and red hats—English wares most popular with natives.
Posts a sentry at the point and organizes his men with clear instructions to wait except for the sentry.
Experiences internal doubt and hesitation about his romantic intentions, showing vulnerability and uncertainty.
Initiates intimate contact and emotional connection with Pocahontas despite uncertainty, demonstrating emotional awareness but possible naivete.
Calls Pocahontas 'my pretty sweet' in a familiar, gentle manner.
Expresses deep frustration with the people around him, describing them as selfish and quarrelsome.
Acknowledges his own restlessness and longing for meaning beyond conflict and comfort.
Reaches for Pocahontas affectionately, showing emerging love and tenderness.
Does not engage in violent or harsh responses to others despite anger and disappointment.
Expresses frustration and disillusionment with the people around him, describing them as fools and selfish.
Reflects thoughtfully on his restlessness and sense of displacement, showing self-awareness about his situation.
Fails to offer a clear solution to the conflict and seems overwhelmed by the challenges he faces.
Expresses deep love and regret for past unkindness, calls Pocahontas his guardian angel and light in the darkness.
Insists on touching Pocahontas’s hand and belly despite her fear, showing a persistent physical closeness.
Promises to take care of Pocahontas, vows never to be a brute to her, shows protective and caring attitude.
Expresses deep emotional vulnerability and longing; admits past unkindness; tries to reconcile and connect genuinely with Pocahontas.
Proposes to protect and care for Pocahontas, acknowledges realistic dangers of the journey back to England.
Fails to immediately recognize or respect Pocahontas's fear and hesitation (she says he must not look into her eyes or touch her, but he insists on holding her hand and touching her belly).
Does not reply to the sentry when asked about his purpose trading with the Indians, hiding something.
Questions the stabbed man and assailant about their fight, showing an interest in resolving conflict.
Feels overwhelmed by the new challenges and fears he might disintegrate under pressure, tempted to return to his former life.
Does not respond when questioned by the sentry about his unsuccessful trade attempt, suggesting he is hiding something.
Expresses frustration and impatience with the colony’s lack of effort, issuing harsh orders and showing rage despite feeling unjustified guilt.
Commands all men to stop their current work and start digging the well immediately; tries to enforce discipline and urgency in colony labor.
Expresses frustration at settlers’ unwillingness to do basic survival tasks like sowing corn and gathering wood.
Feels uneasy and guilty about possibly neglecting duty due to his romance with Pocahontas, though the guilt is described as unjustified.
Thanks Jonson and offers to call on him if needed despite Jonson being contagious.
Engages Wilf in conversation about happiness, showing interest in others' feelings.
Maintains composure and keeps a rational perspective amidst chaos and widespread death.
Offers to call upon a very sick Jonson for help if needed, showing practical leadership and use of available resources.
Interacts calmly with others, attempts to encourage morale by engaging Wilf about happiness.
No indication of losing confidence or taking reckless actions despite deteriorating conditions.
Laughs, showing some lightness and friendliness in a tense environment.
Feels horror and agonizes over his own feelings toward Pocahontas, showing internal conflict and some sincerity.
Orders Ackley’s burial with details spared no detail, demonstrating a respectful and responsible attitude toward a fallen comrade.
Feels physical revulsion at sight of Ackley’s mutilated body, revealing sensitivity and human empathy.
Internally questions his own feelings toward Pocahontas, showing self-awareness but also potential objectification.
Orders the burial of Ackley and instruction to include full details in the morning report despite the unsettling nature of the situation.
Shows hesitation and internal conflict about his relationship with Pocahontas, questioning his feelings and the morality of his actions.
Advises Pocahontas not to put herself in danger by bringing more food.
Tells Pocahontas 'Don’t trust me' and acknowledges he might betray her despite not wanting to.
Expresses genuine appreciation for Pocahontas’ love and concern, admits to feeling conflicted and burdened by his situation.
Advises Pocahontas not to put herself in danger and accepts her generosity cautiously.
Shows hesitation and internal conflict about betraying Pocahontas, struggling to express himself clearly to her.
Admits to Pocahontas that he sometimes feels uncomfortable when seen with her, demonstrating self-awareness and honesty.
Does not explicitly resolve his internal conflict or take decisive action to protect or support Pocahontas or his people in this moment.
Observes Wobblehead's performance silently without mocking, shows respect for the entertainer and does not join in ridicule.
Tells Pocahontas that her dead mother cannot hear her and urges her to speak with him instead.
Maintains respect and dependence of the colonists despite personal distractions.
Shows some emotional confusion about his relationship and new reality.
Responds pragmatically to Pocahontas by reminding her he can answer and is living.
Asks if the crowd was amusing themselves at his expense, showing suspicion and a challenge-seeking attitude.
Confronts a smirking fellow about laughing at him, causing the man to slink away.
Confronts a smirking fellow who may be mocking him, showing assertiveness and awareness.
Questions the crowd's uneasiness and their possible mocking, showing perceptiveness and confidence.
Wanders around looking for confrontation without clear purpose, which may appear impulsive.
Wonders how much the smirking fellow knows, indicating cautiousness and intelligence.
Leads Pocahontas into a field beyond the fort to discuss peace and conflict, listens but shows reluctance to accept peace proposals.
Acknowledges the ownership of the land by Pocahontas' people and concedes they had it long enough.
Dismisses the possibility of living in the woods or taking Pocahontas to England, showing practicality but also a lack of emotional consolation.
Leads Pocahontas into a cleared field beyond the fort, demonstrating awareness of the environment and using a hurricane lantern.
Refuses peace, stating it wouldn’t be accepted and reasoning that the other side has no boats to leave, showing strategic and realistic thinking.
Shows steadiness and confidence when discussing survival and territorial claims, acknowledging limits and challenges frankly.
Does not directly answer Pocahontas’s initial question about how she knows, suggesting a momentary withholding or ambiguity.
Offers beads and bells to Pocahontas impulsively, though horrified at his own actions.
Speaks harshly and shouts, showing emotional distance and cruelty.
Regrets his cruelty and takes Pocahontas by the hand, urging her to come with him.
Acknowledges he cannot do what Pocahontas wishes for the English to leave.
Looks off into the woods, realizes he has compromised Pocahontas, decides he must take a stand.
Shouts to the watchman asking time till dawn, showing urgent management of situation.
Impulsively gives Pocahontas beads and bells, despite feeling horrified at his own action.
Acknowledges Pocahontas has extended herself for the English and tries to console her.
Admits he cannot warn the English or stop them despite Pocahontas's request she can stop her father.
Regrets his cruelty instantly and takes Pocahontas's hand, attempting to protect her by bringing her to the fort.
Calls Pocahontas 'my sweet, my woodland fairy, my saviour' and tries to prevent her from going alone to potential danger.
Follows Pocahontas into the woods attempting to coax her back, showing concern for her safety.
Hides to avoid confrontation with the Indian scouts instead of risking harm to Pocahontas.
Feels guilt and self-reproach for potentially endangering Pocahontas, reflecting on his changed feelings and shaken convictions.
Hides behind a tree upon spotting a squad of Indian scouts, retreats when Pocahontas disappears, indicating caution and situational awareness.
Shows hesitation and emotional turmoil about his duties and decisions, reflecting internal confusion and indecision.
Orders sentry to wake men silently and report, demonstrating decisiveness and leadership under uncertain conditions.
Throws himself on bed lamenting possible harm caused to Pocahontas, momentarily paralyzed by guilt and passion.
Feels a deep, feverish longing for a woman he has hurt, recalling the warmth and abandon of their night together.
Contemplates going to see her despite the danger but ultimately turns back, deciding to think about it later.
Does not reply to Indians’ accusations of betrayal despite their demands.
Engages in single combat despite wounds, showing bravery and resolve.
Sneers at his soldiers and calls them 'stupid as hogs' while showing contempt for their concerns.
Ignores the wounded man's plea and fails to answer his questions about their predicament.
Refuses to beg for favor or compromise his honor despite peer pressure.
Mocks peers and calls them enemies of true nobility.
Feels conflicted about love and the wellbeing of Pocahontas, showing sensitivity to her nature and happiness.
Delights oddly in puzzling his English companions by swimming into danger alone.
Hates himself and the English after Pocahontas leaves, feels deep regret and lost love, reflecting on the impossibility of their happiness together.
Swims farther and farther out, defying the danger of the fast current and hostile Indians on the other bank.
Feels an ache for lost youth and a sense of wasted love, questions what he did wrong and the promise of the new world.
Reflects on the impossibility of transplanting Pocahontas to a civilized town, showing understanding of social and cultural realities.
Refuses to take Pocahontas hostage, stating King James would not approve and citing her past kindness and sacrifices to save lives.
Maintains firm leadership in a stressful situation, refuses to take hostages despite pressure, citing moral and political reasons.
Responds confidently to direct challenges against his authority without wavering.
Shows insight and respect toward Pocahontas' contributions, using this to guide decisions rather than acting impulsively.
Refuses to support mutiny, stands his ground despite threats.
Keeps silent when questioned, which increases suspicion and distrust.
Uses physical force (twisting Argall's ear) in confrontation.
Remains silent in response to Argall’s accusations, showing composure under pressure.
Stands his ground and asserts authority by ordering Argall to return to his post, demonstrating confidence and command.
Reminds Argall and others of the laws and consequences of mutiny, showing knowledge and use of the colony’s regulations to maintain order.
Physically retaliates against Argall by twisting his ear, using surprising assertiveness and physical skill to momentarily dominate the confrontation.
Allowed himself to be overwhelmed and captured by Argall and his cohorts, suggesting possible underestimation of the risk or poor foresight in avoiding being overpowered.
Does not speak up or admit guilt when sentenced to corporal punishment, silently endures harsh treatment.
Survives being keelhauled, maintains composure after severe punishment without pleading or showing weakness.
Remains silent and does not attempt to defend or explain himself when accused and punished.

The excerpt does not show any direct action or indication from John Smith; his possible involvement is only hinted at through Pocahontas' uncertain reflections about a grand gesture or last chance from him.
Is implied to have sent the shallop as a grand gesture to Pocahontas, showing thoughtful or strategic intention.
Does not appear directly in the excerpt to act or intervene, leaving Pocahontas vulnerable to kidnapping.
Mentioned as approaching to meet Pocahontas, implying a role of importance and involvement in tense situations.
Works hard making bricks at the stockade during uncertain times, indicating diligence and focus.
Was against Pocahontas being fetched but apparently unable to prevent it, showing some concern but limited influence.
Forgets what he was going to say when speaking to Pocahontas, indicating a momentary lapse or hesitation.
Calmly endures an attempted stabbing by Pocahontas, protected by his armor, and responds thoughtfully by taking a moment to compose himself and comforting her despite the attack.
Blames Pocahontas for her own choice to come to him, showing emotional intelligence and holding firm to personal boundaries.
Expresses reluctance and hesitation about harming Pocahontas and desires peace over chaos.
Acknowledges appreciation for Pocahontas but then grows angry and emphasizes his own 'civilized' superiority.
Breaks his resolution to leave, showing internal conflict about the situation.
Feels deep remorse and emotional pain upon seeing Pocahontas’s suffering; acknowledges damage he caused her.
Admits to his own feelings of hatred she holds for him without defensiveness.
Offers Pocahontas the knife she used to stab him, indicating a level of sincerity and resignation.
Expresses hatred toward the concept of love and describes love as slavery, showing bitterness and emotional turmoil.
Maniacally pushes Pocahontas into the stable and kisses her forcefully to 'forget' her, an act driven by rage and self-destructive emotion.
Feels trapped emotionally and acts impulsively by ripping open Pocahontas's blouse and pushing her into darkness, showing loss of control.
Acknowledges Pocahontas’s hatred without denial and offers her the knife he was stabbed with, demonstrating acceptance and self-awareness.
Takes Pocahontas into his arms gently, acknowledges his wrongs and expresses deep remorse.
Declines to bring charges against Argall when given the opportunity.
Declines the King's offer and remains with the colony, showing personal conviction without explanation.
Spends stolen, intimate time with Pocahontas, engaging in gentle, playful activities like skipping stones and sharing food.
Declines the King's offer to return and prepare an expedition, indicating independent judgment and firm decision-making.
Does not reply when Newport presses him for reasons, showing restraint or possibly withholding information.
States 'She will not escape,' suggesting confidence in controlling or managing a difficult situation.
Reflects on his impact on Pocahontas, recognizing a change in her demeanor and innocence, showing self-awareness.
Engages in meaningful conversation with Newport about his potential and future, demonstrating openness to self-assessment and ambition.
Looks thoughtfully at the changed landscape and colony, indicating a reflective and observant mindset.
Does not immediately commit to Newport’s suggestion of leading a major expedition, showing cautiousness rather than rash ambition.
Tells Ben to wait two months then tell a woman that he is dead to give her strength and prevent despair.
